India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe, via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alex­andria, at 9 p.m. to-day.

div.head: Cairo Agricultural Show.
div.p: The annual exhibition of the Khedivial Agricultural Society at Ghrzireh will be held between February 14 and 17 next.

div.head: Army Inspection.
div.p: Major General Bullock, C.B., will make his annual inspection of "U" Battery Royal Horse Artillery at Abbassieh at 9.30 a.m. on Friday next.

div.head: New Creek Church.
div.p: The foundation stone of a new Orthodox Greek Churoh was laid at Boulaoon Saturday. The Patriaroh presided at the ceremony, which was attended by a large number of persons. Partnership. Messrs. R. J. Moss and Co., Alexandria, inform ne that, dating from yesterday, they have taken into partnership Mr. Hilary Ernest Collins Moss, the third son of their prior. The style of the firm remains unchanged.

div.head: Cretan Mews
div.p: A great ball was given on the 31st nlto. at the Government building at Canea on behalf of the poor. The occasion was utilised in order to make a great demonstration in favour of the union of Crete with Greeoe.

div.head: Creaks and Turks.
div.p: News has arrived at Alexandria of a serious coLtliot between Greeks and Turks in Samos. Three Turkish soldiers went to the shop of a Greek woman and tried to carry her away. A light ensued, and two Turkish soldiers wore killed and a number of Greeks irjured.

div.head: Encumbrance of Footpaths
div.p: Tc-day the Alexandria City Police began to apply stringent regulations to prevent the footpaths being encumbered by seats outside the coffee houses. In Muhamed Aly-equare a great clearance was effected this morning of these obstructions.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society
div.p: A meeting of the society will take p'aoe at the School of Medicine at 4.30 p.m. to-morrow, when the following papers will be read: Modern Maps of Egypt," by Capt. Lyons, F.R.3., and "The Measurement of Tempera­tures from—250° to + 1500° C-, by Mr. B. F. E. Keeling.

div.head: Creek Naval Lottery.
div.p: 'J he only persons authorised to sell rickets of the Greek Naval Lottery are the oashiers of the Greek Consulates in Egypt, who receive the tickets from Mr. George Kofinas, director of the Lottery Department at Athens. Mr. Phoeaa has no official authorisation to sell tickets and our announcement to that effect was erroneous.

div.head: Polio* Scandal*
div.p: Tl e council of discipline hold to investigate the charges against M. Carasiello, the suspend­ed mamonr of the Attarin Kiem ot Alexandria, has ended, and the documents ot the case have been sent to the Ministry of the Interior. To­morrow M. Carasiello'b successor in the Attarin Rism, Yousbashi Gaoci, is to be brought before a council of discipline. He is aocused of receiving bribes and of other irregularities in the exercise of his tffioial duties.

div.head: Zlzlnla Theatre.
div.p: There will be no performance at the Zizinia this evening. To-morrow night, "Mefistofele" will be given. Mile De Larma, who is to pity the part of Marguerite, has been asked by the management to cede thard'e of Elsa in "Lohengrin" to Mme Maria Grisi. The latter will make her debot on Friday Mr. C Walter has ceded the part of the King in "Lohengrin'' to M. C. Lodonrioo, the former taking the leading r6le in "Mefistofele." "La Tosoa'' was again given last night, and was a great success. The prima donna surpassed even her previoaa performance.

div.head: BIG LAND DEALS.
div.p: KHEDIVE SELLS KOUBBEH ESTATE.

The rnmour that has been onrrent for the past day or two in Cairo,that H H. the Khedive has sold the whole of his estate at Konbbeh, is not quite exaot. The faots are that a British subjeot has seoured the option on one thousand fed dans of the estate, at the price of £3,000 per feddan. The transaction involves a sum of about three millions sterling aud the terms of payment are as to £25,000 in cash within three months, half the balance ot the purchase prioe within 2| yearp, and the remainder within 5 years. On the other hand the German community in Cairo have sold the land on which their chnroh and sohools stand, covering between 3,000 and 4,000 metres, to H.H. the Khedive, at the prioe of £65 the square metre.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT, LTD.
div.p: We understand on good anthority that in the oonrse of the next few days the Corporation of Western Egypt will offer for snbaoriptioD, in London and Egypt simoltaneonsly, the balance (aboot935,0008hares)of their aathorizedoapital of £500,000 in £1 Bhares. The issue will be at par and the local board have scoured 100,000 shares exclusively for Egypt, and preference, in allotment, will be given to shareholders in Egyp^holding folly paid up bearer warrants.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF MAHMAL.
div.p: The annual oeremony of the departnre of the Mahmal took place on Monday. H. H. the Khedive presided, and enormous nnmbere of Egyptians, with many Europeans, were present at a most piotnreeque and interesting speotaole. The Khedive's magnificent oarriage horses were greatly admired and the turn out and general appearance of the troops would have left nothing for the most exaoting Prussian drill-sergeant to criticise. The usual salvoes were fired at the Khedive's arrival and departnre and again on the departnre of the Mahmal for Abbaseieh. About 1,600 Egyptian pilgrims will aooom- pany the Mahmal and its escort to the Holy Places of Islam. We hope that their pilgrimage will be as free from trouble with the Bedonins as was last year's Hag.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive received in private audience on Sunday last Boutros Pasha GhaH, Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Graud Cadi of Egypt, and the Financial Adviser. On Saturday the Khedive gave private audience to Dr Issa Pasha Hamdi, who pre­sented to bis Highness a copy of his latest work on pathology.

div.head: ACCESSION DAY.
div.p: The War Office has issued a notice that residents and visitors who are desirous of wit­nessing the review of troops to be held at Abbassieh by the Khedive on the 8th inst., on the anniversary of hie Highness's acces­sion, oan obtain tickets on application to the Assistant Adjutant General, Egyptian Army, War Office. Itisreqnested that snob applications be marked on the cover "Residents' Carriage Enclosure" or "Visitors' Carriage Enclosure," according to the requirements of applicants. These tickets will not be ready for issue before the 6th inst. The Governor of Alexandria will hold an offioial reception on the 8'h in«t. from 9 a.m. to midday on the occasion of the Khedive's Acoepsion Day anniversary.

div.head: NEW YEARS EVE AT SIIEFHEA RD S
div.p: It iB difficult to write with any accuraoy of the doing! of gay Cairo on New Year's Eve, and the impressions left on tho 'mind after the hall at Shepheard's was emptied of its revellers were of the moBt varied and chaotic description. The evening had started sedately enough, a large contingent of the brightest and best of Savoyards, a number of officers in uniform, and many of the residents swelling the numbers already assembled in the hall and ball-room. Inspiriting musio and a perfect 11 ior inspired people to "chase the Hying hours with glowing feet ; " and it was dose on midnight when the doors of the supper room were opened. Hardly ha I the many merry parties taken their seats before the hour sounded, and every one sprang again to their feet to join in sinking the National Anthem Toasts naturally followed, and an indescribable medley of voices and musio filled the air. The orohestra, which bad taken its place near the door, w .s violently bailed into a more prominent position where one of Cairo's leading finanoiers oould yersonally superintend its efforts; and as popular airs flowed from the nimble fingors of the mnsioians so merry voioes were lifted in chorus till nearly the root was lifted also. The strains of "Auld Lang Syne'' again oarried people to their feet and planted most cf them in orthodox fashion standing on their chairs. Over the remain­ing hours of the evening let us draw a kindly veil. Somebody must have had a heavy bill to pay for broken glass, and if sore heads were rare next morning-the credit most be given to the excellence of the ohampagne provided. The dancing which continned after supper was of that violent order whioh baffles descrip­tion—bat the luck on such occasions is pro­verbial, and perhaps the season was its own exouse.

div.head: GOODS TRAIN DERAILED.
div.p: SERIOUS DELAY TO TRAFFIC
The following telegram was sent to ns yesterday by the State Railway Administra tion : —

Serious delay was caused to passenger train service yesterday morning owing to the derail­ment of a goode train between Sahali and Damaohour stations, causing both lines to be blooked. Assistance was promptly rendered from both sides of the aooident, the down line being cleared by 11.5. a.m., and traffio is being worked in both direotiona on the single line until the other one is oleared. The derailment appears to have been caused by the presence of a fallen ootton bale on the track. The driver and fireman of th9 goods train were slightly injared. No other casualties.

div.head: HONOUR FORM. KLOBUKOWSKY.
div.p: A Havas telegram states that M. Klo- bukowsky, French Diplomatic Agent in Cairo, has been promoted Offioer of the Legion of Honoor, and M. dnzinne has been made a Chevalier.

div.head: EGYPT AND THE KING'S SPEECH.
div.p: The following allusions to Egypt and the Sudan were made in the King's Speech

"The boundaries between the Anglo-Egyp­tian Sudan and the Congo State have been satisfactorily Bottled by an Agreement which has been signed with the Sovereign of the Congo 8tate, and the eastern administrative boundary of Egypt has been delimited by a Joint Commission with the Government o Turkey.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA WATER COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. Cornish, C.M G., managing director of the Alexandria Water Company, has retired, and will be snooeeded in the management of the company by Mr. Blagden. The sub- manager will be Mr. E. Cornish.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: 8aez, Monday.

H. M.'s transport Reva came ont of the Canal this afternoon, and sailed shortly after for Bombay. She is due back at Suez on the 26th Jannary. H. M.'s sloop Merlin will sail from 8uez this afternoon for Port Sudan and Suakin for surveying purposes. The E. T. C. cable ship Eleotra arrived at Suez last Saturday night from Pcrim, and is now moored in the north baBin of Port Ibrahim. The S.S. Tangistan, which was badly ashore on Shabkubl reet, at the entrance ot Suakin, has been refloated after having jettisoned several hundred tons of cargo. She is badly damaged and leaking, and at present anchored at Port. Sudan. The snspeoted oase of plague landed at Moses* Wells by the S.S. Canara on the 26th inst. was proved on examination not to be plagne.

div.head: THE SENOUSSI.
div.p: FROM JARABUB TO ALEXANDRIA.

Salah ben Essaid Omar El Khalidi el Hob- sa'ini, who was reosntly expelled from Tangiers and from Tonis by the Frenoh, and who had to depart from Malta in Ootciber by order of the Governor, arrived at Alexandria on Monday, after journeying overland hither from Benghazi by way of Jarabnb. This we'l-knowa political intriguer, who is the president delegate of the central com­mittee of the Islamic Union and was formerly a "ohargd de mission" in the servioe of the Frenoh Foreign and Colonial Offices, has not, so he informs ns, come to Egypt on any political mission, but simply as a travel­ler. As a member of the sect of the Se- noussi he was enabled to travel through Tripoli to Egypt with great faoility,.and he gives an interesting aooonnt of 'La present state of the Senonssi and of Jarabnb. That town ie the intermediate oentre between Kufra, the headquarters of the seot, and the other head an arte ts of Islam, and at the present time great excitement prevails there and throughout all Cyrenaioa, as the. news has recently arrived from Kufra that the Mahdi is not dead. Four years ago it was believed that the head of the Senouesi had died, and now it is stated that he has merely been wandering about as a dervish all this time and has now appeared to start a Jehad.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM.
div.p: MUSTAPHA KAMEL AND THB "TIMES."

Mustapha Pa9ha Kamel writes as follows to the "Times" :— I was surprised, as were all the Egyptians surprised, to read your Correspondent's mes­sage as well as the article yoo published in your paper with referenoe to the "Egyptian Standard" instituted under the auspices of a company wlrob appointed me as editor and manager. I am perfectly aware that truth may, for political reasons, be sometimes oonoealed, hut I never thought for one moment that jour­nalism, in the high and honourable sense of the word, is liable to untruths or falsehoods. It has always been my deoided oonviotion that true journalists are above oombating their political antagonists by such means as are oondemued by true honour and irreproaohable demeanour. It iB, no doobt, astonishing to find English newspapers at one time unanimous as to the magnitude of the status of the national party in Egypt and the influence it exercises through­out the valley of the Nile in regard to all kinds of movements of which it is deemed the author, and at other times find suoh papers alleging that the party in question is not in a position to institute a company with such a small capital as £20,000. How oan "The Times" ignore, or attempt to ignore the fact that I kept aloof from his Highness the Khedive ever sinoe October 25, 1904 ? Suoh separation was then published in "Al Lewa" newspaper and subsequently quoted by several other papers. I am in a position to state openly that ever since my deolaring my separation I never met, nor did I ever intend to meet'hie Highness. Sach a policy was inten­tionally pursued by me, because I wished to follow aa independent course of conduct not conneoted in any way with offioial oiroles. Snoh a polioy, aa you would no doubt agree with me, would leave no doubt as to the honesty of my intentions and would permit no one to Buspeot my position. It is, moreover, to be born in mind that snoh a step as I have taken in connexion with my relationship with bis High­ness would prevent my being the oause of any political trouble arising between him and his Britannic Majesty's Government. "The Times" would be much mistaken in imagining that I intend to instigate trouble or dietnrbanoe in Egypt, my true intention being to direct all my endeavonrB towards scouring for Egypt a oonstitational Government, true liberty, and the evaouation of British troopp, as waB promised by the late Qieen, Lord Salisbury, Mr. Gladstone, and several other eminent English diplomatists. The English nation bears a great deal of what Lord Cromer writes or says abont Egyptian affairs. This is only the English side of the question, but ont of justice the English nation should a ho know the Egyptian side as well. I venture to state that Egyptian opinions, aspira­tions, and sentiments are very little known in England. The objeotof the "EgyptianStandard" is to supply this want by imparting first-hand knowledge in all matters relating to Egypt and its varied affxirs. This, in my opinion, would be most valuable, as it would help enormously to prevent all misunderstandings between the two nations. The Pasha then gives the list of the foun­ders of 'he "Standard."

Egyptian Prince, with passengers and a general cargo, arrived at Marohester on the 31st alto, from Alexandria.

div.head: MR. DICEY'8 ACCURACY.
div.p: To the Editor of tub "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—While heartily opposed to a polioy of oonoealment of disagreeable political faots, I have always been anxious to depreoate scares, more espeoially when oreated by misinformed correspondents of European and American news­papers. A Cairo contemporary recently gave publioity to oertain amazing statements made by the correspondent of an American joarnal. My only wonder is that anyone oan take such exaggerations seriously. SoaremongeriDg, however, is not the only error of which the Egyptian ooyrespondents of important jonrnalB are occasionally guilty, and I must confess that it was with genuine sur­prise that I read your recent exosrpt from the ' Daily Telegraph." That Mr. Dioey, of all men, the historian of the Khediviate, the contributor to Heaven knows how many journals and magazines, should make error* oomparable to those of Padgett M.P., or the nnmerous olass of writers who give os "Essays on the Afghan problem" after three weeks in India and a three hours' ride E. of Peshawar : I confess I oould not believe my eyes when 1 read yonr excerpt and the original letter in the "Daily Telegraph." Have 1 yonr per­mission to point out a few of the mistakes it contains ? First comes the reproduotion of a rnmour anent Mr. Mitohell Innee, a rumour obviously started by some farceur—too obvious­ly impossible for the belief even of the Egyp­tian public. I grant that it is given as a rumoor, but there are rumours and rnmonrp, e.g., the story published in an Italian contem­porary a conple of years ago of aoonple of young girls reported to have been devonred by oro- oodiles a few miles S. of Roda Island, or the rnmonr which 1 am quite ready to start that M. Paul Oziol and Yoassef Bey Sadik are to be Financial Adviser and Finance Minister after the retirement of the present occupants of those posts. Again, we have Saad Pasha Zaghloul described as an ex president of the committee for the creation of a National University which was started by Mnstapha Kamel Pasha ! The Minister of Eduoation is therefore one ot the Nationalist leader's followers 1 Wonderful I So wondertal that one wonld be inolined to imagine—if another than Mr. Dicey had written the article commented on—that the correspondent had been supplied with in­formation by one of Saad Pasha's most vigo­rous critics. As it is, the correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" has obviously confounded Mustapha Pasha Kamel, editor of "Al Lewa," Tribune of the people, and what not in the way of self-oonferred titles, with the originator cf the University soheme, Mustapha Kamel Pasha El Gamrawi, a notable of the Province of Ghirgoh. Theu we have Yaooub Artin Pasha desiring to resign beoause an English official, young enongh to be his son and unversed in ednoa- tional matters, is promoted over hie head. Well, only Mr. Dnnlop oan here be referred to, and Mr. Dunlop has been twenty years in Egypt engaged from start to finish in educa­tional work, it ie taking rather an extreme view, is it not, to suggest that Mr. Dnnlop has had no experience after all that time? As for Saad Pasha in the gnise of a follower ot Mustapha Kamel Pasha, the idea is too absurd for anything. Where oan the correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" have obtained his information ?—1 am, Sir, etc., A Readbr. Cairo, January 1st.

div.head: UNPUNCTUALITY AT MEALS.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazettb.

Sir,—I came to Egypt in October and have lived in some of the best hotels in Upper and Lower Egypt. Their great reputation is well deserved ; but before leaving the country I wish to protest against the nnpunotuality in aetving the principal meals. In no instance did I ever find any negleot in the bedroom attend­ance. Tha ohoioe of the menu and the oooking were generally excellent ; but 1 cannot reca'l a case in which lanoheon or dinner was served at the hour stated, or carried on with reason­able Bpeed. If the first oonrse was banded round soon after a goest wsa seated he bad simply to wait all the longer for the second. If the system of serving a gues' q iiokly with the menu for tha day between certain hours, as in London hotels, cannot be followed in Egypt, one might at least expeot that if he sits down at the hours announced he should not require to await the arrival of late comers. Of oonrse 1 know that the blame is laid upon the guests ; but finding that there is no advantage in taking their seats at table they naturally prefer to lounge in the ball until ^ooh time as experience has taught them they may expeot to be served promptly throughout the meal. They will be able to finish along with those who sat down in time. This should not be ; and late comers should either have to oontent themselves with the portion of the meal coming on after they have taken their Beats or be served after table d'hAte was over at an extra oharge. This oonrse wonld meet the wishes of nineteen out of twenty of the visitors. Indeed many complained strongly in my hear­ing of the present system,or want of system; and all have agreed that they wonld mnob prefer to lose pnrt of a meal than to be under the neoessity of sitting so long over it as at prepent. Thero is no doubt that if the management wonld exeroine a little firmness the gaests would soon adapt themselves to the altered circumstances, much to the inoreaseof comfort of all oonoerned, both visitor and staff. Your obedient servant, A 8UFFERBB. Cairo, Deoember 81.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Fthmy's health shows a great improvement, but the Prime Minister will probably not leate Mena House before the end cf the month. Saad Pasha Zighlonl h*s left on a tour of inspeotion in Upper Bgyp', where he will be absent for abjnt a fortnigbL The Duke of Connaught, Inspeotor-General of the Forces, will leave England on January 10, on a tour of inspection, and will visit Cey­lon, the Straits Settlements, Hong KoDg, and Egypt. _ 8ir John Harrington, British Agent at Addis A beba, will arrive at Cairo to morrow. He is aocompanied by M. Miohel Beru, dragoman of the Agenoy, who wont with Ras Makonnen on a visit to King Edwaid and King Victor- Emmannel. M. George Proooptas, portrait-painter at the Court of the Negus Meuel k, has arrived here from Athens, and after a month will proceed to Addie Abeba. M. Prooopius oomes of a distinguished old Greek family of Athens. He lately married Athena Phasali, niece of M. Merkurios, Mayor of Athens. He is very popu­lar at the Ethiopian Conrt, and he has several Abyssinian deoorations. Mr. Davies, the newly appointed chiefengineer to the Alexandria Municipality, is expected to arrive here to-morrow. In another oilumn we announce the retire­ment of the managing director of the Alex­andria Water Co., Mr. Cornith, C. M. G. The year 1841 saw the birth of the King, Lord Cromer, and Mi. Cornish, who came to Egypt first in the employment of the well-known engineering firm of Eiston Anderson & Co., at that time (the early seventies) mach oc­cupied in potting up maohinery oonneoted with Ismail Pasha's sugar faotories in Upper Egypt. The same firm had to do with the water works at Beyront in Syria and also with those in Alexandria. After some yoars in the npper country, Mr. Cornish was trans­ferred by the firm to Beyrout in oharge of the water works of that tow^. About 1879 he was appointed manager of the water norka at Alexandria, and although the company has changed hands sinoe then, Mr. Cornish always continued to fill this post, the value of hia servioes having always been fully recognised. During the troublous summer ot 1882 Mr. Cornish's devotion to duty, as well as hia most olever and able arrangments for the defenoe of the W3ter supply of Alexandria, have always elicited the warmest acknowledgment from hie follow oitizens, and, at the time, won for him the honour of a C.M.G. from the British Government. After the maasaore of June 11 Mr.-Cornish despatched his wife and family to Syria, and then, fearing that in the utterly lawless Btate of everything, an attack might be made on the water works, he proceeded to put into effeot a plan of defenoe. Hia first step was to weed out and get rid of all employes on whom he couid not depend—and then he set to work. The defences were arranged by means of hot water and steam pipes, so that, on any attack beiLg made on the building, the defenders conld work those jets and streams of boiling water and steam on their assailants in a manner that wonld ensure preoipitate retreat. After a few days Mr. Cornish beoame suspicious of one of his men, a Maltese, and a very capable workman. The man was despatch­ed on some errand, and daring his absence Mr. Cornish discovered hidden in hie tool-box a min a to and oarefally drawn plan of the bnilding with all its defences I On hia return, the man was met at the gate by the foreman, who paid him his wages, handed him hia tool­box, minos the plans, aioompanied with a few words better imag-ned than expressed ! Next day, during the temporary absence of Mr. Cornish at an out-lying station, the water works reoeived a visit from Arabi Pasha himself, who demanded to be shown over the whole works, and good—naturedly enough, obliged the foreman to take him up to the room in which the deadly hot-water appa­ratus was arranged. Arabi wanted to be shown how the different things worked, but was put off by some exoase by the foreman—happily, perhaps, for his own skiu ! After this, Mr. Cornish kept the big ga'ea closely shut, and forbade any one bring ad­mitted daring his absence, or without hie permission. Probab'y the alarming aooounts of the preparations made to repulse any attack spread amongst the Arab?, for anyhow the water works esoaped unsoathtd amongst the general destruction that ensued after July II, 1882 ; but that the water supply was preserved to the people and oity of Alexandria daring all that terrible summer, was dae solely to the ability, energy, and dpvotion of Mr. Cornish, who so bravely stuck to his post throughout the whole time. Mr. Cornish's career throughout all those years in Alexandria hae been marked by uprightness, ability, and hard work ; whilst his genial, gentle, and absolutely unassuming oharaoter, combined with a most kind and friendly manner, have won for him the regard and friendship of all olassea of hie fellow-citizens.

div.p: Two soldiers of the Imperial Guard kept the whole population at bay, and stopped the entire traffic between Galata and Symbol yesterday, by drawing sword-bayouets and threatening to kill the passers by. div.head: DEATH OF BARONESS
div.p: BURDETT-COUTTS.
A GREAT PHILANTHROPIST.
KING'S AND QUEEN'S SYMPATHY. LONDON, December 31.

Baroness Burdett-Coutts if dead Their Majesties have telegraphed the ex pres-ion of their great regret an! sympathy.(ft.) The graoions and noble lady, who has passed away in her ninety-fourth year, will from her many achievements have a very pro rninent place in any sooiai history of the Victorian Era. In the year of Queen Victoria's aocession, MissBurdett, "theyoungestdanghter of a youngest daughter," inherited the great fortune—a fortune almost unprecedented at that day—of her maternal grandfather, Mr Thomas Contts, under the will of his second wife, who after the death of her husband had married the Duke of St. Albans. Tbriughout the reign of Queen Victoria her life is a story of philanthropy aod charitable work, op a scale such as it has very rarely fallen within the means of any private citizen to attempt There have been few more notable women in oar time than she who shared the fame of Queen Victoria in 1837 'What will they do with it 1" people were asking in that year of two young women—Priuoesi Vototiq who was succeeding t> tile throne of England, and Miss Angela Bordet1-, who hid inherited thirteen tons of English sovereigns. How well the Pnooess Viotoria discharged her heritage all the world knows, and the fame of the .Barouess is scarcely les w .rld-wide. There is hardly a oorner of the Empire in wh:ch she had not oarried her open purse, and where she had not built cathedrals or sent ont emi grants, her work had not been less effective because it had not been advertised to the worl I. She was one of the first Imperialists, and long before it Was fashionable to take an interest in the Empire the Baroness Bardett-Coutts helped to build tip oar Colonies and make the Colonists feel at home. She was a generous friend of General G irdon. and it was through her enterprise that Gordon received his last batch of letters from home The Baroness engaged a Morocco trader to deliver them in disguise, and he reached Khartoum safely. Indireet'y, therefore, the Baroness may be said to have been the last friend in England to oommanicate with Gordon She was oertainly one of the last friends to see him in England. Before going to Khartoum,Cor don speDt almost his last hoars in England at the hoase if Baroness Coatts, and be had a keepsake he foand there present with him to the last. "May I have this fot a keepsake V he askod, picking ap a small letter-case lying on the table, and, little guessing that it would be the last request he would ever make to her, the Baroness allowed him to take it away. "I have received the most indisputable proof," she said, "that Gordoa carried ttyis simple gift in his breast-poeket to the day of his death/' In his own sphere Mr. Burdett-Coutts has achieved a fame not so far-reaohing, bat pot less well earned than that of his wife There is a pretty story whioh, if it ware true, would make the marriage qnite rowaptio -and ro .nantic indeed it was. But it is not trne, as wo have been told so often, that when many years ago the Baroness invited the boys of a school fo lanoh with her only one oalled, and that boy was to be her husband. It is a pretty fiction. Nor is it trne that Mr. Bardett Coatts had a situation in Contts' Bank, or that he was ever in any sense the Baroness's secretary. As Mr. William A-ihmead-Bartlett he had long been the friend ot the Baroness before they became partners in life, and his visit to Tnrkey daring the war, when the Barone-s raised £30,000 in a few days for the distressed peasants, was a purely voluntary and frier d'y undertaking, and not, as it has been repre seated, io the oapaoity of an ''almoner." So, too, was his toar in the West of Ireland, when the Baroness did so muoh to relievo the suffering through the famine. Few women refused more proposals of marriage in their youth than the late Baroness. "Miss Coatts likes me," Lord Hoaghtou once said, "because I never proposed to her. Aim *t all the young meu of good family did ; those who did their duty by their family always did. Miss Browne (Miss Coutta's companion) used to see it ooming, and took herself out of the way for ten minntes, but sbe only went into the next room, and left the door open, and then the proposal to >k place and immediately it was done Miss Contts oonghed, and Miss Brown came in again." There is a good story of the Duke of Wellington which oomes to mind. It was rnmourei soon after Mss Bardett hail oome into her inheritance that the Duke of Wellington was to make her his bride, Bnd an old friend asked the Dnke if the rnmonr hid any foundation. "I said she deserved to ba a Duchess, not that I wonld make her one," the Dnke replied; and when the story was repeated to MLs Coatts Bbe remarked, 'I think the Duke should have said 'could,' not 'woald.' " As is natural with advancing years, she had of late led a retired life ; hat the house in Stratton-street was as hospitable as ever,and its hostess was always glad to welcome her more intimate friends at the informal luncheons for 'Which she was famoas. There was nothing either of the recluse cr invalid about her, and her interest in pnblic affairs was as keen as it ever had been. Her leisure was fully oooupied in attending to her private charity, the extent and usefulness of which will never be known, because she was the last to allow them to be made public. ' Great as have been the intiinsio benefitp," the late Duohes of Teok onoe wrote, "that the Baroness has conferred on others, the most signal of all has been the power of example—-an incalculable auantity which no record of events can

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain D D'A. Alexander, 1st Battalii n Gordon Highlanders, Curk, has been selected i for service with the Khedive's Army, and proceeds forthwith to Cairo. Captain Alexander, who was recently doing doty with the Depot Companies, Aberdeen, joined the Gor dons in April, 1900, from the embodied 3 d BattalioD, then at Edinburgh Castle, and be subsequently joined the 1st JBattalion at the front, and served with it in the operations in the Transvaal, east and west of Pretoria, the aotioDS of Belfast, and Lydenburgh; the operations in Ocapge River Colony (Q-een's medal with three oUeps, and the King's medal with two clasps). Another selection for tho Egyptian Army is that of Lieutenant P.B. Joyce, 1st Battalion Connaught Rangers, Mfl Hi agar. Mr. Jayoe is a smart young subaltern of six and a-half years', experience, and he has had the farther advantage of haviBg seen service in Sonth Africa. He received bis commission in the Rangers in Apiil, 1900, from the Militia, and joined the 1st Battalion in the field the following July, sharing in the harassing operations in the Tram van 1, Orange River Colony, and Cape Colony, in the oourse nf which be was severely wounded (Q LEAN'S medal with three clasps, King's medal with two clasps). Captain Q.C.M. Sorel-Cameron, Cameron Highlanders, on oeaHog to be employed with the Egyptian Army, has been posted to a company in the 1st Battalion at Dublin. On the 3rd January, Lord Manner , D.S.O., King's Royal Rifle Corps, will complete his three years' tenure in the adjntanoy of the 22ud (London Central Rangers) Middlesex V R.C., aud will revert to regimental doty with the K R R.C. Captain G. C. M. Hall, D.3.0, Royal Engineers, on eompleting ten years under the Egyptian Government, io connection with the State RAILWAYS, has been placed on the reserve list. The seutenee of five years' penal servitude paused by a naval oonrt martial on James Abbott, seoond yeoman of signals on II.M.S. Amphitrite, for the theft of a boat's signal book, will no doubt have a salutary effect on any erring official who^pay have a leaning in that particular direction. The actual crime itself was au aimless one, aud apparently without motive, butau example was necessary, for saoh an i ffeoce in time of war might be attended by the gravest oonseqaeuoes. Before leaving the Mediterranean, Rear Admiral Prinoa Louis of Bajttenberg reoeived the oongratulatious of Lord Charles Beresford on the magmfijent performance of his flagship, the Drake, at gunnery, whereby she stands a' the tQp ff( the list. On the homeward inn, the Drake averaged 22^ knots per hour.

div.head: MKSOPOTAMIAN IRRIGATION.
div.p: BV SIR WILLIAM WILLCOCKS.

At a somewhat.late date we bava received » copy of Sir Wm. Willcocks' stady ( f Mesopo tftau**, an amplification of a leotore delivered by bun at a meeting of the Khédivial Geogra ph Oftl Sooie'y in Ca'ro on 25th March, 1903. Tue w irk now before jus oontains valuable contributions in the form of appendice* by other authorities, each eminent in his own sphere. Sir John BBiut, director general of the Meteorological Dept, of tho Indian Government, writes on the Meteorology of Mesopotamia. He nukes a statement of vital importance in writing : "It is my impression that there has been practioally no obaDge in the meteo-ologioal oondition of Mesopotamia." Such an opinion is wvrrantably tenable by examination of the tables of rainfall, tern- perature?, etc., and Mr. Foaden, of the Khédivial Agrionltaral Sooiety, writes : ''A brief examination of the climatic conditions of Mesopotamia leads one to the conclusion that with a kind soil and an efficient system of irrigation, pnotioally all those crops which llmrish under a subtropical son might be successfully grown," Land has largely gone oot of cultivation, reverting iD certain districts to swamp or salt tracts, bat granted drainage ard irrigation the country would easily and rapidly be reinstated to its former oondition of noted fertility. It is the weary story of neglect of the msgniSoent irrigation works of antiquity, regulators and canals on a scale unknown in ancient Egypt, «bioh depended on a basin system far inferior to the system of perennial irrigation beg; nas late as 'he time of M >bamed Aly aud only now being perfec'81 centuries after socb works in Mesopotamia had fallep to ruin and decay. Something out of the wreck night still be saved, though much is irretrievably mined. The Nile is four times the s'sn of the Euphrates and twice the size of the Tigris. Those two rivers, snow fed from the Armenian mountains, approach each other to within a distance of 30 miles at Bagdad, follow a Deltaio oourse of aboot.500 miles, till they unite at Kama, from which point they continue nnder the Dame of the River Basra, till in another 100 miles of oourse the Persian fruit is reached. The Deltaic area rf the two rivers is 6,ijOQ,OQO hectare®, oonsj: derably qaore tfian t>vice the cultivated or cultivable area of Egypt. This enormous ooun- try is divided by Sir W- Wdicocks into 15 proposed Motions, seven on eaoh river and one on the Basra. The figures given for one ot those «dotions, B^gdad-Setenola, are very interesting. The aiea to be irrigated is 267,000 heotares ; estimated oo6t, including interest oharges, £1,000.000, and estimated return on this capital 19 % per annum. The estimates appear reasonable : £2,000,00 for main works and barrages, £1,500,000 for minor oanals and agricultural development, and £600,000 for interest charges. Egypt has a population of about two souls to tfie aore, and fienoe the enormous valae of its agricultural land, bat lack ;of population must form a weak point in deaTing wifh Mesopotamia. The vilayet of Bagdad h^a estimated population of «50,00 U. The tovfn pf Bagdad oRims 100,000 inhabitants. The other principal towuc on the Tigris vary from a fçw hundred inhabitant to Rj.OOO for ^mara. Ou tfie Euphrates the towns are net much better, varying fiom l.OfUinbabi tants to 30,000 for Sliera. Land values must inevitably be restricted by limited population, aud cost of extensive worfcs mnob enhanced by lack of bands. A detailed plan of the Bagdad Sefeucla seo tion is giver, and what strikes one is that the proposed main OAnals aud drains run at right angles to the rivers Iu Egypt, where the slope of the ecu.itry is from santh to north, the main oanals and drains run parallel to the Nile. The slope of Mesopotamia is stated to be the same as Egypt—1/13,000. Every advantage has to be taken of that slope, and channels running at right angles to it mnst be deepened to the tail eüd to produce the necessary fi .-w. There may be unstated reasons f r the proposed alignment. Deeply interesting as theremsk'ng of an ancient country must be, one is forced to consider what chance th re is of the Turkish Government ever allowing the work to be undertaken. That Government has displayed unwonted energy in pushing on the railway to Mecoa. They are doing something with the Hindia Barrage on the Euphrates, but in developing the oanal they have lost the rivet. One would fain see a comprehensive scheme carried oot actively by snob a master of his profession as Sir Wm. Willcocks, llj^the "Dog in the MaDger" may postpone i'*,^ ljQaoy a day. Spaoe does not permit refereroe to tables of discharges taken at various points on the river, and to a great deal of very interesting information, which oven the non-teohnical reader will appreciate. div.head: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DU CAIRE
div.p: VALEURS ASSUREES

Demain à 1A' Chambre Sommaire da Caire aura lien le prononcé d'on jagement qui intéresse an plas haat point toua les commerçants, et môme tous oeax qr, habitant les villages da l'intérieur, expédient de l'argent aux mai sons de banqnes du Caire.
Voici les faits :

Un entrepreneur de Damiatte avait envoyé, il y a quelque temps, à la National Bank, au Caire, one lettre assurée contenant 10 bank- notes de 10 livres égyptiennes, soit une somme de 100 LH. Le soas-ohef oomptablfl le la Na tional Bank, M. Hioks, ouvrit le pli en qoer- tion, et y trouva, en guise de bank-notes dix feuillet» de papier blanc.

La Banque réclama la somme k l'expéditeur et k l'Administration des Postes. On fit des enquêtes, mais on ne put retrouver les bank- notes disparues. L'entrepreneur avait assigné la National Bank et l'Administration des Postes égyptiennes en paiement dudit montant. D'après lui, la responsabilité de la Banque ne saurait être mise en doute. Ou a négligé de vérifier l'enveloppe avant de la décacheter, et cependant oette enveloppe portait des traoes d'effraotion, qui furent constatées au cours de l'enquête. Si la National Bank avait fait cette vérification, elle eut, elle aussi, constaté l'effraction, et alors elle ne devait ouvrir le pli qu'en présenoe de l'employé des postes préposé à la distribution des plis assurés. La National Bank répond qu'elle n'avait pas k s'occuper de tout oela; une lettre éta:t arrivée, le sous-oomptable l'ouvrit et ayant oonstaté l'absence de tous billets il fit iœmé diatement la réclamation à la poste, laquelle s'empressa d'ouvrir une enquête. Il y eut, au contraire, ajoute t i', fautefj^expéditeur pour n'avoir pas expédié sa lottw^nians des conditions de séourité plus grandes et n'avoir pai mis lea billets de banque dans nne double enveloppe intérieure. Sa faute est enoore plus grande de n'avoir pas indiqué dans sa lettre ou tout au moins oonservé cüez lui les numéros des billets. L'Administration des Postes, k son tou.-, ne voit pas pourquoi sa qualité d'intermédiaire l'engagerait k nnerespoDsabilitéqueloor.que.ELle a reçu une lettre assurée qui fut régulièrement livrée au destinataire moyennant déobarge. La Poste ignore le contenu des lettres, même assurées, et il aurait fallu que la National Bank fassn la constatation au moment de la ré oeption. Qui, des trois plaideurs, paiera les 100 LE î c'est oe que nous saurons jeudi proch lin.

div.head: THE IBRAHIMIEH PLOUGHING COMPANY.
div.p: L' "Ibrahimieh Plongbiog Tempany" a tenu samedi son assemblée générale. Nous empruntons à notre confrère 1' ' Orient" le compte-rendu résumé, ci après, de cette réunion : "Du rapport du Consei1, il résulte que l'ex ploitation a donné une recette supérieure de £ 1,769 aux dépenses, trais généraux indus ; cette somme est de droit destinée k l'amortissement. L'exeroico ne permet pas de distribuer on dividende ; l'Ibrahimieh Ploughing va faire appel k la garantie que la Société des Sucreries loi a souscrite en mai 1905. Le oonseil expose ensuite les difficulté* qrule krach Cronier a suscité k l'Ibrahimieh Ploughing ; sur le produit de l'émission de mai 1905, qui devait être de Lst 93,600, M. Cro nier a disposé personnellement de Lst. 71/296 d'où procès devant le Tribunal de Commerce de la Seine ; les Conseils légaux de la Sooié'é loi proposent de nommer des arbitres. La faillite des Sucreries a amené celles-ci à vendre au gouvernement les voies ferrée qu'elle» avaient recueillies de la Deira Sanieh. L' Ibrahimieh Ploughing y perd une partie des faoilités que la Société des Sucreries lui faisait pour le transport de ses laboureuses. Elle proteste oontre la situation qui lui est ainsi fa>te L'assemblée réunissait 14,950 actions sur 24,000 et comprenait 967 voix.—On y voyait entra autres, MM. Mille1", Carton de Wi*rt, Merzbach, Arbib, Spitzar, de Vries, Guil hanmou, Tnrabian. Les comptes furent approuvés par l'assem blé», k l'exception des voix de MM de Vrie- et Guilhaumou, qui firent des réserves. Pois l'assemblée donna pouvoirs an Conseil pour nommer des arbitres, et s'il le jugeait convenable, pour le règlement par voie de justioe des sommes distraites par M. Cronier A ce moment, M. G.iilhaumon exposa que, d'après loi, il n'était pas opportun de parler de tranaaetjAi! alors qu'un dépôt de bilan pou vait être nécessaire k brève échéance. Le préd^gnt lui demanda oomment on pouvait o^ncevotr un dépôt de bilan, alors quels Sooiété n'a pas do Créanciers. Puis l'assemblée ratifia la nomination de MM Naos et Pbilippar! comme administrateur, à l'unanimité, moins M de Vries, qui déclara persister dans Bon système de réserves. Vint alors le moment de désigner les cen sears, —M. de Vries, demanda la parole et, dans le silence religienx de l'assemblée, il pro posa la nomination de Yonssef bey Baddik, et M. Gailhanmon, celle de M. Oziol — L'as semblée désigna MM. Merzbach et Naville An moment de la clôture, M. de Vries dorme leoture d'one note comprenant une série de question» auxquelles le rapport du Conseil avait réponda par avance — Il demaude que oette nota soit jointe au procès verbal, ce k quoi le bureau aocède. £lt 1A aéanoe est levée."

Municipalité d'Alexandrie
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la foorniture de tnyanx en grès nécessaires à ses services pendant l'année 1907. Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 90.

La cahier des charges est dépo an buren de la Voirie où il peut être consulté pat le» intéressés toos les jour» de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés. div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.
